title: Chris Jones (rugby union)
text:
Christopher Michael Jones (born 24 June 1980 in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>) is a retired English <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> rugby player. He played as a <a href="Lock%20%28rugby%20union%29">lock</a> or <a href="Flanker%20%28rugby%20union%29">flanker</a>, featuring for <a href="Sale%20Sharks">Sale Sharks</a> and <a href="Worcester%20Warriors">Worcester Warriors</a> in the <a href="English%20Premiership%20%28Rugby%20union%29">English Premiership</a> and <a href="Yorkshire%20Carnegie">Yorkshire Carnegie</a> in the <a href="RFU%20Championship">RFU Championship</a>.
His rugby union career blossomed at <a href="Stockport%20Grammar%20School">Stockport Grammar School</a>. He went on to take a Business Studies course at <a href="Sheffield%20Hallam%20University">Sheffield Hallam University</a> and was two years into it when the <a href="Sale%20Sharks">Sale Sharks</a> invited him to join them. He played for Cheshire at U18 and U20 level, then briefly with <a href="Fylde%20Rugby%20Club">Fylde</a> before joining <a href="Sale%20Sharks">Sale Sharks</a>.
He made a startling rise to the <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">England Sevens</a> squad, and was nominated for the 2003 PRA Young Player of the Year Award. He was part of the <a href="England%20Saxons">England A</a> team that beat <a href="France%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">France A</a>, <a href="Scotland%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland A</a> and <a href="Italy%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy A</a> in their 2003 <a href="Rugby%20Union%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">Six Nations</a> and also went on the unbeaten England tour to North America and Japan that year.
He played for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> in the uncapped match against the <a href="Barbarian%20F.C.">Barbarians</a> at <a href="Twickenham%20Stadium">Twickenham</a> in May 2003.
The year 2004 marked another leap forward. He was called up to the senior team by then head coach <a href="Clive%20Woodward">Clive Woodward</a> from the start of the <a href="2004%20Six%20Nations">Six Nations</a>. He came off the bench against <a href="Italy%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy</a> for his debut cap and scored a try. This earned him a starting position against <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> as a <a href="Flanker%20%28rugby%20union%29">flanker</a> and again against <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> from where he continued to impress. He was selected for the <a href="2004%20England%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20Australasia">2004 Summer tour</a>, starting against the <a href="All%20Blacks">All Blacks</a> in Dunedin in the first Test.
Sale Sharks director of rugby <a href="Kingsley%20Jones%20%28rugby%20union%2C%20born%201969%29">Kingsley Jones</a> referred to him as 'the most hard done-by player in England' after he was hardly used during the 2005 Autumn test series.
Jones went on to collect more <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">caps</a> on the <a href="2006%20England%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20Australia">2006 Summer tour of Australia</a> and <a href="2007%20England%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20South%20Africa">2007 Summer tour of South Africa</a>.
In the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Guinness%20Premiership">2005–2006 season</a>, Jones started the final as <a href="Sale%20Sharks">Sale Sharks</a> won their first ever <a href="Guinness%20Premiership">Premiership</a> title. He was also voted Sale's player of the year in 2006 and again in 2008.
On 22 May 2014, Jones officially joined <a href="Yorkshire%20Carnegie">Yorkshire Carnegie</a> in the <a href="RFU%20Championship">RFU Championship</a> on a two-year contract from the 2014-15 season. 
On 19 May 2016 Jones announced his retirement from rugby after suffering a concussion against <a href="Nottingham%20R.F.C.">Nottingham</a> in April of that year.
Personal life.
Jones married Donna on 28 June 2008 at <a href="Dromoland%20Castle">Dromoland Castle</a>, <a href="County%20Clare">County Clare</a>, <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a>. They live together in Cheshire.
Donna gave birth to their first child on 10 April 2009, Daniel William Jones. Their second child, Alánnah Monica Jones on 14 November 2011. 
Their third child, Harrison Peter Jones on 23 February 2014 and their fourth child, William Christopher Jones was born on 22 September 2015.
